physDesc.p: There are also a number of additions and emendations by the Tremulous Hand of Worcester.

handNote.p: Ker's scribe 'P'. The scribe Eadric. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule. Quite upright in character. The top of flat-topped g is quite short compared to the width of the descending loop. Tongue of e short and clubby, e is horned in a similarly 'clubby' manner. Miniscule eth of unsual form, with tall, swooping ascender, and curly cross-stroke that extends only to the right. Bellies of thorn and wynn bottom-heavy, round and p-like. Some forking and flagging to the tops of ascenders, while descenders of thorn, f, r, long s tend to have a flick to the left.

An addending hand generally using a somewhat more finely-cut pen. The hand is marked by its tendency to leave a small gap at the top of e and fondness for an upwardly-curling long tongue on e. This hand sometimes adds interlinear Latin glosses or 'vel'-alternatives in other homilies. The same hand can be seen in other places in Hatton 113 and Hatton 114, generally inserting words either by extending the descender of a letter downward to mark the intended insertion area, or using a double-punctus marking. This is the same hand as that identified by ECHOE handID DP1032a.
